specific_issues.description:
FY 2017 Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration and Related Agencies Appropriations Bill: Legislation that provides funding for the U.S. Department of Agriculture and Food and Drug Administration. Of interest to the organization are funding for USDA's Agriculture in the Classroom program and provisions affecting the administration of farm and conservation programs as well as animal health and meat inspection programs.
FY 2017 Energy and Water and Related Agencies Appropriations Bill: Legislation that provides funding for the Department of Energy, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (Civil Works), Department of Interior, etc. The organization is concerned about the allocation of federal funds within the Corps' Missouri River budget between the Missouri River Recovery Program and the Bank Stabilization and Navigation Project. Other key policy provisions of interest to our organization include those pertaining to "Waters of the U.S." and the Endangered Species Act.
FY 2017 Interior and Environment Bill: Legislation that provides funding for the Department of Interior, Environmental Protection Agency, Forest Service and related agencies. Of interest to the organization are provisions concerning the Waters of the U.S. final rule/Clean Water Act, Endangered Species Act, and Worker Protection Standards rule pertaining to on-farm pesticide use.
FY 2017 Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and related Agencies Appropriations bill: The organization is monitoring discussions concerning the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (PSM) standard. The effect of OSHA's interpretive memorandum would be felt most significantly on establishments that sell anhydrous ammonia in large quantities, and as a result, will impact farmers' access to and price of anhydrous ammonia.

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. SENATE, U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

specific_issues.description:
The organization supports replacing the current federal income tax with a system that is simple, transparent, revenue-neutral and equitable. As such, we are closely monitoring discussions in the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. We are also supportive of extending certain temporary tax provisions.
Jobs and Premium Protection Act (S.183/H.R.928): Legislation that would repeal the tax levied on a health insurance company's net premium. The tax was included in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, which Farm Bureau opposed. The organization supports S. 183/H.R. 928.
Death Tax Repeal Act (S.860/H.R.1155): Legislation that would amend the Internal Revenue Code to repeal estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes. The organization opposes the estate tax and therefore supports S. 860/H.R. 1155.
Marketplace Fairness Act of 2015 (S.698): Legislation that would allow each member state under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement to require all sellers not qualifying for a small-seller exception to collect and remit sales and use taxes with respect to internet sales. Remote sellers with less than $1 million annual sales are excluded; those who are above the threshold would be provided software for collecting the tax. The organization supports fair competition between local and main street retailers and internet-only sellers. The House companion bill is H.R. 2775, the Remote Transactions Parity Act.
Farm Equipment Depreciation (S. 2202/H.R. 4474): Legislation to permanently reinstate five-year depreciation for farm equipment. The organization supports this change since agriculture is an equipment-heavy industry.

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. SENATE, U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

specific_issues.description: Reducing Regulatory Burdens Act of 2015 (H.R.897): Legislation that would amend the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) and the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (CWA) to clarify that CWA permits are not needed when a pesticide is applied in accordance with a FIFRA-approved label. The organization is concerned about the potential for duplicative permitting requirements, thus approves of the proposed clarification. A similar bill, the Sensible Environmental Protection Act of 2015 (S.1500), is pending in the Senate. Language from this bill was offered and approved as an amendment to the Bipartisan Sportsmen's Act (S.659), which is also pending in the Senate.

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, U.S. SENATE

specific_issues.description: "Waters of the U.S." Final Rule: The organization has serious concerns about the final rule issued by the EPA and Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) to define the scope of waters protected under the Clean Water Act. Our concerns were detailed in comments submitted to the docket. The organization supports The Regulatory Integrity Protection Act of 2015 (H.R.1732) and The Federal Water Quality Protection Act (S.1140) to prohibit the agencies from moving forward with the rule and directing them to consult with state and local officials before writing a new rule. The organization supported action through the Congressional Review Act to disapprove the WOTUS rule (S.J.Res.22 and HJ.Res.59).

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. SENATE, U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Army - Dept of (Corps of Engineers)

specific_issues.description:
Regulatory Accountability Act (H.R.185): The bill would amend the Administrative Procedures Act (APA) to require agencies to be more open and transparent on data used to justify a rule. The organization supports H.R. 185.
Regulations from the Executive in Need of Scrutiny (REINS) Act (S.226): Legislation would require Congress to vote on every new major rulemaking proposed by the Executive Branch, which has an annual economic impact of $100 million or more. The organization supports S. 226.
The Providing Accountability Through Transparency Act (H.R.690): Legislation would require each agency, in providing notice of a rulemaking, to include a link to 100 word plain language summary of the proposed in regulations.gov. The organization supports H.R. 690.
The Searching For and Cutting Regulations That Are Unnecessarialy Burdensome Act of 2015 (SCRUB Act)(H.R.1155): Legislation that would establish a bi-partisan commission to review the Code of Federal Regulations and specify rules that should be repealed based on certain criteria. The organization supports H.R. 1155.

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, U.S. SENATE

specific_issues.description:
Safe and Accurate Food Labeling Act of 2015 (H.R.1599): Legislation that amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to create a uniform, national system governing the premarket review and labeling of foods containing genetically engineered ingredients. The organization supports the measure.
Biotech Labeling Solutions Act of 2016 (S.2609): Legislation that amends the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to require the U.S. Department of Agriculture to establish a national voluntary labeling standard for products containing genetically modified ingredients. The organization supports S.2609.
Genetically Engineered Food Right-to-Know Act (S.511): Legislation which directs the Food and Drug Administration to require food manufacturers to label foods containing genetically modified ingredients. The organization opposes S. 511.

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, U.S. SENATE

specific_issues.description:
Trade Negotiations: Improving market access for all U.S. agricultural commodities and products and resolving sanitary and phytosanitary trade barriers are our priorities. The organization has supported congressional efforts to urge the Obama administration to make market access and trade barrier resolution priorities as well, particularly with regard to Japan. The organization is monitoring the Trans Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership negotiations. The organization supports the Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP).
Cuba Trade: The administration is moving to remove trade restrictions on credit and banking with Cuba as well as exploring re-establishment of diplomatic relations. Legislation, such as S. 491, has been introduced in Congress. The organization supports normalization of trade with Cuba.

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. SENATE, U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

specific_issues.description:
Farm Bill: The President's budget proposal for FY 2017 calls for a ten-year $18 billion cut in the federal crop insurance program. The organization opposes this recommendation.
Crop Insurance: A bill (S.345) to limit the premium subsidy provided by the Federal Crop Insurance Corporation to agricultural producers to $50,000 is pending in the U.S. Senate. The organization opposes the bill because changes in the federal program were considered and made during the 2014 farm bill debate.
Safeguard American Food Exports Act (SAFE Act; S.1214/H.R.1942): Legislation that would prohibit the sale or transport of horses for purposes of human consumption. The organization opposes S. 1214/H.R. 1942.
The Commodity End-User Relief Act (H.R.2289): Legislation that reauthorizes the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) through 2019. Other provisions of the bill would allow for greater protection of customer funds held by financial entities, relax certain Dodd-Frank requirements, and limit CFTC regulation of cross-border derivatives trading. The organization supports reauthorization of the CFTC.

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. SENATE, U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

specific_issues.description: Executive Order (EO) 13690, issued by President Obama on January 30, creates a Federal Flood Risk Management Standard (FFRMS) for all federally funded projects. The organization has concerns about potential implications for farmers, land owners and communities and submitted comments during the formal comment period.

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. SENATE, U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

specific_issues.description:
Common Sense in Species Protection Act (S.112): Legislation that would require the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to publish and make available for public comment an economic analysis outlining costs to the public from the listing of a species under the Endangered Species Act as well as designating critical habitat. The organization supports S. 112.
The State, Tribal, and Local Species Transparency and Recovery Act (H.R.2352): Legislation to require the federal government to supply all data used in determining a species' status to affected states before a listing decision is made. The organization supports this bill to provide transparency within the Endangered Species Act.
Missouri River Management: A letter was sent to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers from Members of Congress (whose districts lie within the Missouri River Basin) expressing opposition to Missouri River Master Manual revisions that could result from the Missouri River Recovery Management Plan/Environmental Impact Statement process. The organization encouraged Members in the Missouri Congressional delegation to cosign.

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. SENATE, U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

specific_issues.description:
Health Care Reform (H.R.596): Legislation that would repeal the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) and the health care provisions contained in the Health Care and Education and Reconciliation Act of 2010. The bill then would require specified committees to develop legislation addressing various issues pertaining to health care. The organization supported passage of the bill.
Simplifying Technical Aspects Regarding Seasonality Act of 2015 (STARS Act; H.R.863/S.1809): Legislation to amend the Internal Revenue Code to align the definitions of seasonal worker and seasonal employee as a worker who is employed on a seasonal basis for six months or less during the calendar year for the purposes of Affordable Care Act (ACA) compliance. The organization supports the clarification to the ACA.

ali_info.federal_agencies: U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, U.S. SENATE

specific_issues.description: Corn Ethanol Mandate Elimination Act of 2015 (S.577): Legislation that would amend the Clean Air Act to revise the renewable fuel program by eliminating the annual renewable fuel standard that requires 36 billion gallons of renewable fuel to be blended into transportation fuel by 2022. The bill would not affect separate requirements for advanced biofuel, cellulosic biofuel, or biomass-based diesel. The organization opposes the bill because our member-adopted policies favor the development and use of renewable energy from feedstock produced on farm and ranch lands as part of a comprehensive national energy policy that includes traditional, renewable and alternative sources.

Energy Policy Modernization Act (S.2012): Legislation that contains provisions to increase energy efficiency, improve the nation's electric grid, and invest in energy research. The organization is monitoring possible amendments to the bill pertaining to the issues of electric power transmission, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's policy governing Process Safety Management Standard that affects agricultural retailers, and the Renewable Fuel Standard.
